div.head: Regarding the Text
div.p:
Praedictis adiciendum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 23, c. 1.
. This is distinction 23 in which after the Master treated about the divine names in general, now he considers them specifically.

And he divides it into three parts, for in the first place he shows how person is said in the divine, in the second how numeral term is predicated in the divine, and in the third place how the term of a plural number applies to the divine persons. The second part begins at the beginning of distinction 24 at
hic diligenter
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 24, c. 1.
. The third at the beginning of distinction 25 at,
praeterea considerandum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 25, c. 1.
.

The first part is divided into three because in the first place of this name because it is the person from some relative thing previously given he introduces an exception, in the second places he introduces a useful question, and in the third place he introduces a review or recapitulations of the things said. The second begins at
ideo hic oritur quaestio
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 23, c. 1.
. The third begins at
iam sufficienter ut puto
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 23, c. 5
.

The second principal part, which is distinction 24, is divided into three because in the first place the Master puts a conclusion, in the second place he recites the opinion of others, and in the third place provides a solution to the question. The second begins at,
si diligenter
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 24, c. 1.
. The third begins at
cum enim dicitur, unus Deus
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 24, c. 1.
etc.

The third part, which is distinction 25, is divided into three because in the first place the Master asks whether this name person signifies the divine essence, in the second place he puts the intention of others, and in the third place he offers his own response. The second begins at
quibusdam videtur
Lombardus, I, d. 25, c. 1.
. The third begins at,
sciendum est ergo
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 25, c. 2.
etc.

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether the same concept in number is able suit properly and formally God and creature; whether some names found in scripture are formally proper to God and creatures.

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p: That not because then, just as true number is posited and found in creatures, so true number would be found in the divine. The consequent is false because number is a real accident which in no mode should be posited in the simplicity of the divine essence. The consequence is clear since the trinity of divine persons is not less than the trinity of created persons, as is seen, therefore.

In the second place, there no single concept for God and creature, therefore no name properly suits God and creature. The consequences is valid, and the antecedent is proved because God and creature differ more than substance and accident.

In the third place, God is not nameable and a creature is, therefore. The consequences is valid, and the antecedent is from
Augustine in on the words of the lord, sermon 34
Whatever is able to be spoken is not ineffable, but God is ineffable
Augustine, Sermons Sermo 17, c. 5, n. 7 (PL38, 665)
, therefore. Again, through the
author of De causis, in proposition 6 , saying,
the first cause is above all speaking and languages fall short of its telling
Liber de causis V (VI)
.
The Master seems to be in opposition from distinction 21 up to 26 exclusively, therefore.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
The first conclusion: though number secundum quid is obtainable from corporeal things, nevertheless number absolutely is in discoverable in spiritual things. The first part is proved because number is a plurality of unities or several unities, therefore number secundum quid in is able to be posited in corporeal unities. The consequences is clear because, if several unitieis are number, it follows that those unities which are not unities absolutley but secundum quid do not constitute number absolutely but secundum quid, but in corporeal things nothing is one absolutely, therefore. This is clear since any such things is composed from several parts or uniities, namely from matter and form. The first antecedent is able to be had from the
Philosopher
Aristoteles, Physica III
and the
Commentator III Physicorum
Averroes, Physica III, commento xxx
. The second part is proved because number absolutely is unity absolutely or plurality of simple unities, but this kind of simplicity is only found in spiritual things, therefore.

The first corollary: that when taking number for a any plurality of really distinct things then number absolutely should be put in the divine. But if it were taken for plurality of some things neither existing or constituting one thing through itself, in this way should
number be totally removed from the divine persons. The first part is clear because the blessed trinity is a true plurality of persons distinct from one another. The second is proved because these persons are one through themselves essentially because something composed having parts at the same time is not called number because they are one this something, therefore a fortiori the uncreated trinity, since it is one most simple essence, is not number in the mode taken. And in this sense should the authorities be taken which say that there no number in the divine. The corollary is from
Gregorius, in distinction 24 of book 1, article 3
Gregorius Ariminensis, Sent. I, d. 24, a. 3.
.

Second corollary: that no number absolutely is an accident inhering formally in numerated things. This is clear since no accident should be put in God and number absolutely is there. This is confirmed because, if number were an accident, either it divisible or indivisible. Not the first because no number is divisible into many numbers, as is clear from a binary. Again, should any of these numbers have parts it would be able to be asked about them without end. Nor the second since every quantity is divisible as is clear through the
V Metaphysics
Aristoteles, Metaphysica V, xxx
. And nor is it able to be said that it is divisible into unities, since numeric unities are not superadded to numerated things, but are things themselves. It follows that number is not a divisible accident. Again, it follows that the same accident would be in many things separated in place by a maximum distance. The consequences is clear because the number one hundred of men/to man would be in some of them, since there is not a greater reason for it to be one than in another or in all. This is the corollary of
Gregory mentioned above
Gregrious Ariminensis, xxx
. The opposite of this
is held by Thomas de Argentina and he responds to this argument in distinction 28, article 4
Thomas de Argentina, Sent. I, c. 28, a. 4
.

Third corollary: that no number taken absolutely and properly depends on an act of the intellect or a numerating mind. This is clear because otherwise when such an acts ceases number would cease, and thus when a disordered rich person does not a florin would cease to have the number which it previous had, indeed this person would have neither more nor less than any poor person. The consequence is clear because where there is not number there are not are not rich and poor, nor more or less discretively or numerically. This corollary is from
Thomas of Argentina
lio
in distinction 24
Thomas de Argentina, Sent. I, d. 24.
. For which things it is clear that just as no one thing per se is several men, so no number is one thing, but many. This is clear because it is numerated things. See
Gregory where mentioned above
Gregorius Ariminensis, xxx
.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
The second conclusion: that any divine supposite conveying absolute perfection is able to be said properly and formally of God, It is proved because God is formally that which is in anything is better it is than it is not, therefore. The conclusion is true. The consequence is valid. And the antecedent is from
Anselm Monologion 15
Anselmus, Monologion 15, xxx
. Note nevertheless that this description of
Anselm
ought to be understood thus, that perfection absolutely is that through which, for any single thing in which it is, it is better that it is than if it were not in this, and were not this, and were not in it formally, and were not in another equivalently or virtually, from which it follows that Anselm's description of absolute perfection in itself and in the sense which it makes does not seem true. This is clear because, so understood, it would follows from this that nothing would be absolutely perfect. The consequence is clear because nothing is that which for every single thing is better than not being because either this would be the creator or creature. It is not the creator because it would not be better for me to be God than not to be God because through being God I would become not me. Nor would this be a creature because it would not be better for God to be a creature than not to be a creature. Therefore some gloss Anselm, saying the following,
absolute perfection is that which in a single thing in which it is, is better for that thing that if it were not in that thing.
xxx . But this does not suffice because then hotness has 10 degrees and it would not be absolutely perfect. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because, if this charity were removed from me, and if another charity were given to me
of a thousand degrees, it would be better for me than before, and nevertheless I would not have that which I had before, and consequently to have this would not be a kind of absolute perfection, which was the derived consequent.

The first corollary: that some names implying negation or privation signify the divine nature perfectly and an immeasurable perfection. This is clear because an unmeasured, infinite, and immensity, infinity, signify the divine nature and perfection, and nevertheless they are negative names, therefore. The antecedent is clear from
Richard, III De Trinitate, chapter 9 , saying,
we have production because the divine substance is nothing other than his own immensity.
Ricardus de Sancto Victore, De Trinitate II, 7
.

Second corollary: no name purely negative or privative is perfectly declarative or expressive of the divine essence. This is clear because such a name says perfection absolutely, therefore. The antecedent is clear because such a name does not speak what the thing is, but what it is not.

The third corollary: no name said about God temporally speaks a perfection absolutely or suits God formally. This is clear because any such name is able to not suit God. This is confirmed because otherwise it follows that God would more perfect after the creation of the world than before. This is clear because in the creation of the world God began to be, since this name is said about God in in relation to creatures, as is show by the
Master in distinction 22
Lombardus Sent. I, d. 22, xxx.
.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p:
Third conclusion: though God is not perfectly knowable or conceivable by us in this life, nevertheless in this life God is nameable by us in some mode. The first is clear through the Prima patet per
Apostle in I Corinthians 13
now we know God in part and imperfectly
I Corinthios 13:12 . The second part is proved because that which we conceive or are able to conceive in some mode, we are able to express and name that through names, since words are signs of the passions and coneptus of the mind. But through the first part, we are able to conceive God in some mode, therefore.

The first corollary: that no mental or vocal name is properly univocal to God and to creature. This is clear because the world being seems most especially to be univocal and common to them, but this is false. This is clear because God suits the created being less than an accident does with substance.

The second corollary: though God is conceivable and nameable by us nevertheless the concept of him cannot be placed in any category. This is clear because then the term of the category would be said univocally of God and creatures, which is false. This corollary is against
Gregory, in book 1, distinction 8, question 3, article 3
Gregorius Ariminensis, Sent. I, d. 8, q. 3, a. 3.
.

Third corollary: though no proper name found in scripture is properly univocal of God and creatures, nevertheless the same mental and vocal name is able to signify God and creature analogically. The first part is clear by taking proper name univocally and strictly because no such thing is suitable to God and creature. The second part is clear when taking proper name loosely and for any concept significative of a thing by analogy or in some manner equivocally.

div.head: Objections and Responses
div.p: Against the first conclusion and corollary: first every number absolutely properly said is a plurality of quantums, but in the divine itself in innumerable things there is not plurality of quantums, therefore. The major is clear because every such number is a type of quantity because it is discrete quantity, as is clear in what has been proved. The minor is clear because no immaterial thing is a quantum.

In the second place against the second corollary, it follows that numerated things are number. The consequent is false because then some numbers of the same species would be unequal. The consequence is clear because six men and five are of the same species because all men are of the same particular species, and nevertheless they are not equal numbers. Again in the same mode, it follows that equal numbers will be of diverse species, just as quaternary of roses and a quaternary of violets. The consequence is clear because rose and violent are distinguished in species.

In the third place, it follows that some substance would be quantity. The consequence is clear since every number is quantity and numerated things are substances. The consequent is false, both because
every quantity is an accident, and because substance and quantity are diverse and distinct categories.
In the fourth place, it would follows that the one seeing a crowd of men would know the number of them because the number of them and those men are the same.

Against the second conclusion, God and creature are totally distinguished from one another and agree formally in nothing, therefore no ratio abstracted or taken from one would formally suit the other, therefore no name abstracted from a creature is said formally of God. The consequence is clear because, if such a ratio were to fit any of them, this would not be totally formally distinct, but rather would agree formally in something, which is repugnant to what has been said.

In the second place against the first corollary, if some negative name were said about God formally this would either be through information or identity. Not the first because the most simple act is not able to be the subject of something through what is informed. Nor the second because then privative and the negative would coincide through identity and would really be the same thing, which is false.
In the third place against the second corollary, infinity is as negative as incorporeality, but infinity is formally said about God, therefore.

Dionysius I De divinis nominibus
seems to be against the third conclusion, saying,
God is unnamable by us because we do not name anything that we do not know by any thought
Ps-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus I, xxx.
. But, as he shows in the same place, we do not know God by any thought, therefore.

In the second place, there ought to be a certain proportion of any sign to its significatum. But no proportion is able to be between some mental and vocal name and God, therefore God is conceivable by no concept.

In the third place against the first corollary, every intellect certain about one concept and doubtful about others has a concept about which it is certain different from the concepts about which it is uncertain. But the intellect of the pilgrim is able to be certain about God by doubting about finite or infinite, created or uncreated being, therefore the concept of being about God is different from the this or that concept. Therefore neither by itself is included in both, therefore it is not univocal to those things.
Scotus, in book 1, distinction 3, question 2
Scotus, Sent. I, d. 3, q. 2.
. See
the arguments of Thomas Argentina
Thomas de Argentina
.

Against the second corollary, everything that is predicated truly in quid about a pronoun pointing to some thing and about a pronoun pointing to another thing specifically distinct from it, nevertheless not about anything, that is a genus or category of that thing. But this is the case regarding this name spirit with respect to God and other things, therefore God or his concept is able to be found in some category. The minor is clear because this name spirit is predicated in quid about of a pronoun demonstrating God and angels, there spirit is a genus to God and angels, and consequently God is in some genus.

To the first, the major is able to be denied because a ternary of angels is number absolutely and properly said no less than a quaternary of horses. In the second place, it is said that there quantity of perfection suffices because in spiritual things this is greater because it is more perfect. However any divine suppose is immeasurably perfect, though they are not three immensely perfect substantially distinct things, nevertheless they are truly three of which something is immensely perfect.

To the second, the consequent is conceded, and to the proof, that unequal numbers are of the same species of this genus which is number, is understood in two ways. In the first way, that the same most specific species of number is predicated of each number, in this way the consequence is denied. In the second way, that they are of the species of some other genus, like of substance or of quality, in this way the consequence is conceded. And the consequent as true is not proved false in this sense, but in the first place in the same mode said to the second by conceding the consequent, for two men and two horses and any other two things are in the same species of number inasmuch as they are two, but inasmuch as they are men, the others are horses, they are diverse in species, nor is this inconvenient because the same thing in diverse modes is in diverse
categories.

To the third, the consequent is conceded, and I say further wither Gregory that not every quantity is an accident. In the second place, it is said that, though substance and quantity are distinct categories, nevertheless they are able to be predicated of the same thing.

To the fourth, it is said that one seeing the whole crowd of one sees the number of a man and the one seeing a crowed of a thousand men sees the number of a thousan, but it does not follow that he sees those men determinately to be a thousand.
Gregory offers the example
Gregorius Ariminensis, XXX
.

To the first against the second conclusion the consequence is denied because in this way it would be proved that a horse would not be formally an animal because man and horse are themselves formally distinct and agree in no from the part of the thing, therefore the concept of an animal abstracted from on of them would not suit the other, and thus either man would not formally be an animal, and if this is true, the horse will not be formally an animal. In the second place, I say to the form that the argument only proves that the ratio abstracted through the intellect by a creature does not suit God formally outside the intellect because this common and abstract ratio does not have real being, but is only a being of reason. Nevertheless it does not follows that goodness and wisdom and things of this kind do not suit God formally.

To the second, it is said that through the identity and the inferred consequence is denied, therefore the positive, etc., because, though these terms infinity, immensity are something privative with respect to the word, nevertheless not according to the thing or the signification.

To the third, what is assumed is denied, nevertheless for the matter of the argument I say that some names are negative according to the thing and word, some according to the word, and some absolutely, concerning the first is the invisibility in sound, concerning the second immensity, infinity, concerning the third ignorance, blindness. See
Alphonsus, distinction 22 of book 1, article 2
Alphonsus Vargas, Sent. I, d. 22, a. 2, xxx
where he puts several distinctions of types of names.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said that this authority and similar doctors intend that in life we are not able to know God perfectly, nor even to name, but we are only able to name him imperfectly, as the conclusion says.

To the second, it is said to the antecedent that it suffices that the sign is imposed on the signified by some property which exists in the signified in reality and appears in some mode or is expressed in the signified. Nevertheless it is not necessary that between the sign and the signified there is a proportion through adequation and equality because otherwise a circle would not able to be a sign of wine, for it suffices that there is a proportion according to imposition.

To the third, the major is denied because the intellect is able to be certain about a disjunct created from two contradictories and to be doubtful about each, just as in this case, Plato is or is not, and nevertheless it is not necessary that he has a distinct disjunctive concept. Whence when a bachelor is equivocal of a bachelor in theology and medicine and you know the following both that Peter is a bachelor in theology and John in medicine, and you do not know which of them is the theologian and which is the medical doctor, then you are certain that Peter is a bachelor and that John is a bachelor, but you also do not know whether each one is a bachelor in medicine or in theology. Therefore through this mode of arguing this term bachelor is different from each of these and is included in each, therefore it is univocal, which is false. Therefore it is clear that the argument does not conclude.

To the fourth, the major is denied unless it were predicated about these things univocally and according to the same quidditative reason. In the second place, the minor is denied because it is not distinguished specifically from something. And when it is said that spirit is predicated about, etc., there the consequence is denied because it is not predicated univocally about them. Whence Augustine denies that God is substance where substance is one of the ten categories because the divine essence is not contained or limited by any category. Therefore Dionysius says that
God is not being but above being Dionysius, xxx

To the first in the opposition, the consequent is conceded, and to the disproof it is said that the consequence is not valid because, as was made clear above, this number is not different from the supposites.
To the second, it is said what was said in the third conclusion.
To the third, it is clear how God is imperfectly nameable by us and in someway knowable by us, and this suffices.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p:
Praedictis adiciendum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 23, c. 1.
. First conclusion: that this name person is said to itself and according to substance and it is said individually about each person, for the Father is a person an the Son is a person, and the Holy Spirit is a person, and nevertheless they are not called one person, but three persons.

Second conclusion: that from this related things, namely because the names which signify substance, are said individually of each person and of everyone individually at the same time, person is removed from number because it is not said about three things at the same time in singular but in plurality.

Third conclusion: that the Greeks say three substances, that is three hypostases and one essence, the Latins says one essence or substance and three persons, such that the Greeks understand the word substance differently than the Latins.

Fourth conclusion: that we do not say three gods because scripture contradicts this, nor do we say three substances or essences lest diversity is understood in the highest equality with respect to essential things. But we say three persons because even if scriptures does not say it, nevertheless it does not contradict it.

Fifth conclusion: that God is not called diverse nor singular nor single nor solitary because singularity or the solitude of the persons excludes plurality of the persons, but diversity destroys the unity of the essence.
Sixth conclusion: that intrinsically there is no diversity, even if the saying is sometimes found, three diverse persons, that is distinct.
Seventh conclusion: that because in God there is no diversity or multiplicity, therefore God should not be called manifold, but triune and simple.

Hic diligenter
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 24, c. 1.
. This distinction 24 contains nine conclusions. First: that when it is said, one God, a multitude of gods is ruled out and quantity of number in diversity is not posited. Similarly, when it is said, one is the Father, one is the Son, the ratio of what is said id that there are not many father nor many sons, such that these names are posited more greatly for excluding those things which are not in God than for putting something there. Note nevertheless that here the
Master
is commonly not held, where he says that
numerical names are only said of God privatively and they do not posit something nor say something positive.
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 24, xxx
.
Second conclusion: that when we say, many persons are in the deity, we exclude singularity and solitude, we do not put diversity or multiplicity there.\

Third conclusion: that when we say, three persons by the name of ternary, we do not put quantity or some diversity in God, but it is understand that neither the Father alone, nor the Son alone are in the divine, but there is also the Holy Spirit. Similarly, not only is there this person or that persion, but this, that, and that other.

Fourth conclusion: that when we say, the Father and Son are two, not one, and not binary which is the quantity of duality, we do not posit quantity, but we signify that not only the Father and not only the Son, and this is not that.
Fifth conclusion: that when it is said, there are distinct persons or there is a distinction in the persons, we exclude confusion and mixture, and we do not signify that this one is not that one.
Sixth conclusion: when we say, this one and this other one are persons, we do not posit there diversity or otherness, but we exclude the Sabellian confusion

Seventh conclusion: that there discretion is taken in the same mode in which distinction is taken, and distinction or discretion is suitably said to be there, but not diversity, division, or separation

Eighth conclusion: that when it is said, Trinity, the same thing seems to be signified, that three persons, et just as Father is not bale to be called three persons, so neither is it able to be said that the Faither is Trinity or the Son is Trinity.

Ninth conclusion: that when Isidore says that truth is singular, he understands singular for that which others understand to be one, but when he says that Trinity is manifold and numerical he understands multiplicity and numerosity,
just as the others understand thrice/trinum.

Praeterea considerandum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 25, c. 1.
etc. This distinction 25 contains three conclusions. First: that the name of person in the divine serves a triple ratio in the Trinity. For sometimes it makes an understanding of the creature, as when it is said, Father is the a person, the son is a person, the Holy Spirit is a person, that is essence

Second conclusion: that this name person sometimes make for an understanding of the hypostasis or subsistence according to the Greeks, as when it is said, one thing is the person of the Father, another of the Son, another of the Holy Spirit, that is, one is the hypostasis of the Father or another subsistence according to the Greeks.

The third conclusion: that this name person sometimes is taken for a property, as when it is said, one is personally or another is personally, or the Son is personally, that is, the Father by his own property is other than the Son, and the Son by his own property is other than the Father, for by the paternal property the hypostasis of the Father is distinguished from the hypostasis of the Son with the filial property and the Holy Spirit by procession property is distinguished from each. And these are things for this present distinction and consequently for the entire lecture.
